items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-04 – Mitigated Negative Declaration for Calero High School Modernization Project:  California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Compliance
	 
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt the attached Mitigated Negative Declaration.  In doing so, the Board declares that the Calero High School Modernization Project would not have a significant effect on the environment.
	 
The proposed project consists of the modernization of Calero High School in accordance with the provisions of the 2008 Measure E Bond and to consolidate the continuation high school and the independent study program and post-senior program currently operating at other District school sites.
	 
Overall the project will increase the current campus capacity to 500 students, a net overall change of 280 students from current operations. Calero High School will operate a morning and an afternoon session, which offers the District double the normal capacity of classroom usage and consolidates the classroom space.
	 
Calero High School will be comprised of seventeen (17) total classrooms including standard classrooms, a science and laboratory classroom, a computer room/library, a multi-purpose room and administrative office space. The 10.08 acre site is occupied by a 38,772 square foot two story school building, two parking lots, and outdoor play fields and associated landscaping. The total floor area is 38,272 square feet. The existing staff parking lot (Lots A and B) provide 49 total spaces.
           
The existing building foot print is not being expanded. The construction and site improvements include the following features:
Expansion of  staff parking Lot A  from 24 spaces to 54 spaces
Expansion of staff  parking  Lot B from 25 spaces to 54 spaces
Construction of a 39,029 square foot parking lot providing for 97 student parking spaces (Lot C)
Remodel and reconfiguration of administrative office/school entry
Classroom improvements
Reconfiguration of the bus loading area
Refurbished and reconfigured paved play areas
New landscaping, sidewalks, fencing and signage
The extension of utilities and associated site work
The new parking Lot C will be constructed adjacent to Lot A with access from Calero Avenue. The new parking lot will cover an existing league baseball field, which will be relocated just south of the new parking lot, mid-parcel along the eastern edge of the school site. The baseball field at the southeastern corner of the site will be refurbished as follows:  skin the infield, add dug-out benches, replace the backstop and chain link safety fencing where needed. The construction and the improvements to the baseball fields are not components of the East Side Union High School District bond measure project; it is under the purview of the baseball league.
	 
A necessary aspect of this project is compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA). The primary purpose of CEQA is to inform decision makers of the environmental consequences of their actions through the completion of an initial study and environmental evaluation of potential impacts, and to identify and mitigation measures that will be employed.
	 
An initial study was prepared for the Calero High School Modernization Project in conformance with the requirements of CEQA. The initial study concluded the project could have a significant effect on the environment but there will not be a significant effect in this case, because mitigation measures have been agreed to by the District as conditions of approval for the project and as such, a Mitigated Negative Declaration will be adopted by the Board of Trustees.
	 
Comments have been received from the California Department of Toxic Substances Control and will be addressed in a revised draft proposed resolution to be provided to the Board and will be made publicly available in advance of the scheduled meeting.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-04 – Mitigated Negative Declaration for Calero High School Modernization Project:  California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Compliance.

FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Robert Ibarra, Coordinator of Professional Development/Migrant Education
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. Regarding Resolution#2011/2012-05 Sufficiency of Textbooks and Instructional Materials
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
Education Code Section 60119 required that the local Board of Education hold a public hearing and declare by resolution whether or not all students have access to sufficient instructional materials consistent with the State curricular frameworks and standards.  If the Governing Board finds an insufficiency, it must be made known to the public the reasons for the insufficiency and take action to ensure that the situation is remedied within eight weeks from the start of school.  This public hearing is intended to comply with the regulation.
	 
Please be advised that the present California State per pupil allocation for the purpose of instructional materials is sufficient to provide each student with the instructional support materials for each class for school year 2011-2012.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The administration recommends the the Governing Board determine a finding of sufficiency in instructional materials and supplied as specified in Resolution #2011/2012-05 and hold a public hearing with due diligence on September 15, 2011, as required by the Education Code Section 60119.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator, and Rogelio Ruiz, Esq., Legal Counsel 
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve Proposed Amendment Measure "E" Program Management Agreement
	 
The Measure “E” Bond was passed by the voters in 2008. The District and SGI entered into this certain “Agreement for Program Management Services” dated as of September 18, 2008, (the “Agreement”) whereby SGI provides program management services for the District’s Measure “E” bond program. The Agreement was for a three (3) year term and expires on September 19, 2011. In an effort to maximize taxpayer dollars and to make the bond program more efficient, Administration is conducting a detailed review of the scope of the program management services, past performance and the existing terms of the contract to identify any weaknesses and/or opportunities to implement improvements in processes, services or the contract terms.
	 
Administration is recommending a ninety (90) day extension of the Agreement to allow the Administration sufficient time to complete its review. Administration will present its full recommendation to the Board at a subsequent regular meeting before the expiration of the ninety (90) day period.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
No increased or additional fiscal impact; Program Management fees will continue under same terms as in the current Program Management Agreement.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE: 
Measure “E”
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board approve the extension of the Program Management Agreement for a period of ninety (90) days to and including December 19, 2011, and authorize Administration to execute the attached “AMENDMENT TO AGREEMENT FOR PROGRAM MANAGEMENT SERVICES (MEASURE “E” GENERAL OBLIGATION SCHOOL FACILITIES BOND PROGRAM)”.  The proposed amendment includes the ninety (90) day extension as well as modifications to the existing contract to address and implement recommendations made in the January 2010 FCMAT Extraordinary Audit regarding contract services.

The proposed amendment includes the ninety (90) day extension as well as modifications to the existing contract to address and implement recommendations made in the January 2010 FCMAT Extraordinary Audit regarding contract services.

PREPARED BY:

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding requests for Physical Education Exemption
	 
	 
Description:
Education Code Section 5124(c) and Board Policy 6142.7 state that the governing board of a school district or the office of the county superintendent of a county may grant permanent exemption from courses in physical education if the pupil complies with any one of the following:
	 
Is 16 years of age or older and has been enrolled in grade 10 for one or more academic years.
Is enrolled as a postgraduate pupil.
Is enrolled in a juvenile home, ranch, camp school where pupils are scheduled for recreation and exercise.
	 
Additionally, students must have completed 9th grade physical education and have satisfactorily met at least five of the six standards of the physical performance test pursuant to section 60800.  Students under this exemption are not allowed to attend fewer total hours of classes if he or she elects not to enroll in a physical education course.
	 
While the recommended students meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code 51241(c) these students are in 11th grade and still have ample opportunity to satisfy the State/District graduation requirement of 2 years of Physical Education.
	 
	 
Student A
Student B
Student C
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
	N/A
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees deny the recommended physical education exemptions.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees deny the recommended physical education exemptions.

SUBJECT:
Public Hearing Notice at Approximately 6:15 p.m. regarding Resolution #2011/2012-06 Gann Spending Limit
			 
			 
In accordance with the California Education Code, a public hearing is to be held prior to the adoption of Resolution #2011/2012-06 Gann Spending Limit. 
			 
The Gann amendment limits the growth rate of income for state and local governments including school districts.  Each year, school districts and other agencies affected by the Amendment must calculate their Appropriations Limit for the coming year.  There is not direct relationship between the figures, which appear in the calculations of the Gann Limitation and other 2011/2012 budget data since the calculation deals exclusively with the proceeds of taxes
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

SUBJECT:

Attached for your review is a copy of the 2010-11 Unaudited Actual Financial Report.  The report provides a detailed summary of the District's fiscal status as of June 30, 2011.  Your approval is required to certify the 2010-11 Unaudited Actual Financial report as required by Education Code 42100.  In addition, your approval will establish appropriations to account for differences between the estimated year-end balances and the unaudited year-end balances as required by Education Code 42600, prior to submission to the County Office of Education and to the State.  The formal due date to the County Office is September 15, 2011.
			 
INCLUDED IN YOUR PACKET:
A detailing of General Fund revenue and expenses for FY 2010-11, estimated actual vs. 2010-11 unaudited actual.  Also included are detailed summary information highlighting the same type of information for each fund including special revenue funds, capital project funds, and proprietary funds.  All summary worksheets prepared reflect the information required by the State for Unaudited Actual which are shown on the SACS forms.
A powerpoint presentation highlighting the 2010-11 Unaudited Actual Financial report.
			 
ESTIMATED ACTUALS vs. UNAUDITED ACTUALS
Each year districts are required to include an estimate of the ending fund balance for each fund with the Budget Adoption process.  It was estimated when the budget was adopted that the General Fund ending fund balance would be $30,141,048, and the Unaudited Actual for the General Fund totals $35,346,463.  The variance between the estimated actual vs. unaudited actual represents an increase of $5,205,415, to the 2010-11 ending fund balance which has been brought forward into the 2011-12 budget year as an increase to the beginning fund balance for the General Fund. 
			 
Board action is requested to approve the 2010-11 Unaudited Actual reports as presented with permission to proceed with any additional final year-end adjustments that may be necessary.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept and approve the Unaudited Actual for 2010/2011 fiscal year.

Item:  12.07
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Request for One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to Allow for a Fireworks Display at W. C. Overfelt High School on October 15, 2011
			 
			 
On Behalf Of:  
Sergio Cervantes, ASB President 
Elizabeth Verdusco, ASB Vice President
Maria Burgara, ASB Secretary
Nina Kathrina Vinoya, ASB Treasurer
Students of W. C. Overfelt High School are requesting that the use of fireworks/pyrotechnic display be approved on a one-time basis.  This display is for homecoming game and 50th School Anniversary celebration. 
			 
Board Policy 5142.1 prohibits the following at the school sites and on District facilities: (1) open fires including Bon Fires of any type; (2) pyrotechnics of any type; and (3) explosive devices such as firecrackers.  Various schools have requested a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for the planned fireworks/pyrotechnics display for their homecoming game and the school's 50th Anniversary celebration.
			 
Administration recommends Board approval of the one-time waiver on the following conditions:
This is a one-time waiver only.
The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate governmental permits, licenses and approvals no later than one week before the planned event.
The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide proof of adequate liability insurance coverage for the event (including but not limited to an endorsement naming the District as a additional insured), to be determined by Administration, to be provided at least one business day before the planned event.
The fireworks/pyrotechnics displays shall be staged in a safe area.
The school shall obtain adequate security and public fire safety personnel and equipment on site during the scheduled event.
No other fireworks of any kind shall be allowed on the school campus.
The pyrotechnic companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus including but not limited to the athletic and activities fields.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
ASB Funds
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve request for one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at W. C. Overfelt High School subject to above conditions and the approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.

Item:  12.08
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Establishment of District Bank Clearing Account
			 
			 
In order to address recurring Audit Findings related to non-ASB moneys being deposited into site ASB bank accounts, the District is recommending that a clearing account be established to allow school sites to deposit miscellaneous and/or non-ASB funds to the clearing account.  The district’s recommendation is based on discussions with the district’s external auditor Vavrinek, Trine, and Day who have stated that the clearing account would be an acceptable solution to ensure that financial transactions are not commingled between ASB and non-ASB funds.  In addition, there have been discussions by the district’s internal audit committee as to the need to address this on-going concern. The district’s Business Office will work with sites to ensure that the deposited funds are easily transferred from the clearing account to the County Treasury and credited to the appropriate school site accounts within the District’s Accounting System.  
			 
Ed Code 41017 permits the Governing Board of any School District or any school under its jurisdiction to establish one or more bank accounts as clearing accounts to deposit any miscellaneous receipts including donations, allowable class fees and other fees.  All moneys deposited in the clearing accounts shall be paid into the County Treasury within the time periods specified pursuant to Section 41001 and made available for site use. 
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board approve to establish District Bank Clearing Account as described and authorize the transfer of funds from the Clearing Account to the County Treasury.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  13.01
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and John Lawrence, Assistant Director of Maintenance
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Deferred Maintenance-Capital Fund Projects
		 
		 
The district is requesting the Boards approval to allocate $27.8 million of the remaining $40 million in Measure G Bond funding to address critically needed deferred maintenance projects throughout the district.  The work is being contemplated for completion within the Measure G Bond language which allows the district to provide greater security and safety, relieve overcrowding, improve technology and make other facility improvements and renovations as contained within exhibit "A" of the ballot measure.  The district has a total authorization amount of $298 million to repair, build, and equip its facilities. 
		 
In developing the attached recommendation, the district's Maintenance and Operations departments first performed a facilities assessment of all district sites over a 2 - 3 month period.  Next, the department prioritized projects based on each project's condition, age, annual maintenance costs, and safety concern.  Those projects with the highest scores were deemed as high priority and were given an assessment score of 1, the next group of projects were given a 2, and the remaining projects were given a 3.  The district is recommending that the projects be completed over a span of 3 summers beginning with priority 1 projects in the summer of 2012.  Priority 2 projects would be completed in the summer of 2013, with priority 3 projects scheduled for completion in the summer of 2014.
		 
The projects will be completed in coordination with the Measure E projects, where applicable.  The district anticipates transferring program oversight to the district's Bond Program Manager, for the coordination of project scheduling and administration once the projects have been approved.  The district's deferred maintenance projects would be subject to review by the Citizens Bond Oversight Committee and annual audit since the projects would be implemented with Measure G funds.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$27.9 million
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the list for Deferred Maintenance-Capital Fund Projects as presented.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  13.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, in Consultation with SGI 
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action for Calero High School Project Measure E Budget Increase
		 
		 
In February 2009, the Board approved the use of $29.5 million in Measure E Bond Program funding for the purchase and modernization of the future Calero High School in the south end of the District.  Of this, $20 million was allocated to the purchase of the site and $9.5 million for modernization of the facilities.  At that time, plans called for modernization consistent with general education use of the facilities.
		 
Since that time, plans for use of the site have become much clearer.  Working closely with the Instruction Division, the program for the site now includes 1) a Post Senior Program, 2) a Virtual Learning Program, and 3) a Continuing Education School.  Each of these three (3) programs serves unique student populations and has unique facilities requirements.  Also, the Continuing Education School and the Post Senior Program both have significant requirements for site use - a dedicated drop off area and secure outdoor area for Post Senior students and adequate off-street parking for Continuing Education students. 
		 
None of the impacts discussed above as a result of the change in program focus could have been anticipated in the original budget because the costs were originally based on a general education model.  As these requirements have been redefined and clarified, it has become increasingly difficult to meet the revised programmatic goals given current budget requirements.  The district believes that each of the three (3) programs planned for the Calero High School site is of significant importance and to the learning community in the south end of the district.
		 
The project team has worked collaboratively with the Instruction Division to determine where opportunities for cost cutting exist.  As this process proceeded, it became increasingly difficult for the project team to recommend any reductions that would not compromise the intent of the programs.  The project team was able to reduce some site improvements and perform some value engineering resulting in some reductions in costs.
		 
The present plan for the Calero High School, resulting from these actions, requires a total budget of $14,175,862 for modernization of the building and site.  The district is currently projecting a budget shortfall of $4,675,162 from the original project budget.  The district has identified a total of $2.1 million that could be shifted from Alternative Education ($1 million) and the discontinued district education center project ($1.1 million).  The remaining $2.5 million would be needed from any remaining Measure E project authorization.  The district anticipates that the Calero School may be eligible for state matching funds and is planning to submit an application to that effect.
		 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify reallocation of $2,178,632 from unused funding in the February 2009 Alternative Education budget and, further, that the budget for the Calero High School Modernization be augmented with $2.5 million from the Board Contingency Budget.  In the event the district is successful in its application and receipt of state matching funds for this project, $2.5 million could be returned to the Board Contingency Budget.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$4,675,162 (increase)
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E Bond Program
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
Adopt a revised budget of $14,175,162 for modernization of the Calero High School facilities and site.
Ratify reallocation of $2,178,632 from within Alternative Education budget of February 2009, and District Education budget; and
Authorize transfer of $2.5 million from the Board Contingency Budget - said transfer to be reimbursed upon approval and receipt of state matching funds.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  13.03
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve the Recommendation for the "Measure E & G" Pre-Approved Construction Management Firms (CM) List
		 
		 
The East Side Union High School Administration is pleased to present to the Board of Trustees the following recommendation to expand the current CM pool. The original CM Pool was established at the March 10, 2009 Board Meeting where by four Construction Management firms were selected and approved. However, since that time it has been determined by Administration that having more CM’s in the pool would benefit ESUHSD so as not to over burden any one firm at any one time.
		 
After an extensive evaluation of the proposals submitted and oral interviews with each of the seven new proposers, the following listed firms are recommended to provide construction management services for the ESUHSD’s Measure E and G Bond Construction and Capital Improvement Programs and any other projects that require such services.  As projects come up all firms in the Pre-Approved CM Pool will be requested to submit a separate cost proposal and will be awarded projects based on their proposals.
Blach Construction Company (Existing)
Facilities Management Planning and Operations – FMPO (Existing)
SGI Construction Management – Seville Group (Existing)
O’Connor Construction Management (Existing)
TBI Construction & Construction Management, Inc. (New)
RGM and Associates (New)
Van Pelt Construction Services (VPCS) (New)
Cambridge CM. Inc. (New)
Kitchell (New)
United Compliance Corporation (New)
The District underwent a thorough Request for Statement of Qualification (RFQ) process (RFQ-03-11-12). The RFQ was released on August 04, 2011 and closed on August 18, 2011. The RFQ was advertised on August 08, 2011 and August 15, 2011. The District received eleven (11) responsive and responsible proposals.
		The first step in the evaluation process was to evaluate each of the eleven proposals submitted to the District. The four (4) current (CM) firms were only asked to update the District of any change in their organization or information that they want to include.  The current (CM) firms were not required to go through the evaluation process and I interviews.  A committee was established and a rating sheet prepared for their evaluation of the written proposal. The committee consisted of Tom Herrington 
(Substitute Director of Facilities), Donna Bertrand, C.P.M. (Contract Administration Coordinator), Grettel Castro-Stanley (Principal), Mac Cage (Interim Director of Information Technology Services), Edward Bright, (Grounds Lead) and Janice Unger (Capital Projects Purchasing Manager).
Seven CM firms were then recommended to move forward to the oral interview based on the scores of the written proposal evaluation. The oral interviews were conducted with the same panel members.  All CM firms were scored on their presentations and responses to District questions.
		The third and final step in the evaluation process was to call the references. The references were asked to rate the past performances of the seven CM firms using a scale of 1-10.
		All of the scores were added together to form the final recommendation that would be taken to the Board of Trustee, which is presented herein.
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the following recommendations for the "Measure E & G" Pre-Approved Construction Management Firms (CM) List.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of August 2011
				 
				 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of August 2011, in response to board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
				 
				 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
				 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
				 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Warrant Register for the month of August 2011.
